entry.title: Combined summary - HTLC Endorsement for Jamming Mitigation
entry.summary: The email thread discusses various aspects of the HTLC endorsement model and its implementation challenges in the Lightning Network. One of the main concerns raised is the lack of transitivity of reputation acquisition cost between hops, which creates vulnerabilities for the endorsement scheme. The speaker suggests that nodes should put a higher bar than reputation revenue if they consider having a high reputation with another node crucial.There is also a discussion on the effect of dynamic reputation windows on payment reliability. Sudden changes in link throughput based on HTLC resolution might break the historical liquidity buckets of routing scoring algorithms, potentially affecting payment reliability. However, the exact implications of this are uncertain.The email provides updates on the upcoming call for channel jamming, scheduled for May 1st. The goals of the call include gathering data on the use of HTLC endorsement and local reputation tracking to mitigate jamming. Different algorithms for tracking local reputation will be experimented with. Minimal changes required to add HTLC endorsement are outlined, suggesting a binary endorsement field as a starting point.A two-part scheme for mitigating channel jamming is proposed. Reputation is suggested for slow jams that are easily detected as misbehavior, while unconditional fees are proposed for quick jams that are difficult to detect. Each node tracks the reputation of its direct neighbors and allocates slots reserved for endorsed HTLCs from high reputation peers.The email highlights the distinction between routing fees and reputation revenue in the HTLC endorsement model, using an example of two nodes, Caroll and Bob. The compensation mechanism in this scenario is unclear, and the speaker suggests that there may be coupling effects between historical liquidity buckets and the introduction of an endorsement scheme. Further information on the LDK scoring engine is provided through a link.In the Lightning Network community, channel jamming has been a prevalent issue. To address this, a two-part scheme involving HTLC endorsement and reputation is proposed. The email emphasizes the need for reputational transitivity between incoming and outgoing traffic. The team plans to gather data during the weekly calls to mitigate jamming and experiment with different algorithms for tracking local reputation. The email also mentions the interest in deploying an experimental TLV value for HTLC endorsement.The vulnerability of the Lightning Network's endorsement scheme is discussed due to the lack of transitivity of reputation acquisition cost between payment path hops. The speaker suggests that the acquisition cost of local reputation should be equal to the maximal time value damage one can inflict on a routing node channel accessible from its local counterparty granting this high-level of reputation.In summary, the email thread explores the challenges and uncertainties involved in implementing effective routing and compensation systems in the HTLC endorsement model. The Lightning Network community is actively working towards mitigating channel jamming and experimenting with various schemes and reputation algorithms to achieve this goal.
